don't be deceived by the rows and rows of sushi rolls. if you take a closer look, they're all the same! they just mix and match unfresh salmon, eel and avocado on top of all the rolls to throw you off. boo.

This is a decent spot for sushi. The quality is about average, but you have the choice of 20-some different kinds of sushi (nigiri, rolls, and one fried roll). Some highlights were the salmon nigiri, yellow tail, Philadelphia rolls,  salmon skin rolls, and the cooked salmon with avocado roll. They also had nice tempura, and cooked dishes. There's a ramen bar which I didn't try...so I can't really comment. There were also ribs which weren't bad and snow crab. There were several desserts.

Cons: some of the fish sits out a little too long. The yellowtail was getting a little old. The snow crab appeared to be brined which I didn't like. The tempura roll was subpar, because it was unattractive, lacking sauces, and the salmon got cooked. The desserts were boring and unmemorable.

When this place opened, many years ago, this was the place where we spent many family celebrations (my side). And we hadn't been there since, until a few sundays ago, to celebrate my sister's birthday (cinco de mayo- we work so we couldn't go out on monday).

I made a reservation for our large party- 14 of us (my mom, my siblings & their children, only one missing was my brother-in-law). Good thing, too, because when we went to the door, before it even opened (11:30 am), there were about 30 people standing to get inside. Busy lunch time crowd. The staff managed well. We were seated in the back part. We had a high chair, but our little one was sleeping. (We woke him after he had a nap so he could enjoy some fried rice and teriyaki chicken.)

Food was fresh (all the cooks were busy), there was a sushi station, salad section, hot foods section, (personalized section- you select the veggies) & a dessert section (ice cream is handled by the attendant). I liked the many different selections but I was trying to keep myself comfortable, so I was being picky, but I was satisfied. I wanted some Kale Salad, and then upon closer inspection, noticed that I got a lot of the thick stems (next time, I'm gonna be that annoying person that picks at it, avoiding the stems. For the most part, I ate what I selected, and I enjoyed my food. I also saved room for dessert. I got the green tea ice cream but it was a little off (then again, it almost always is, at these places, unless you go to a specialty ice cream place). 

My husband just thought it was OK, but thought it was a little high-priced, and actually likes Todai better (no doubt, the crab legs are quite tasty there). I remember my sister saying that our mom saying likes Krazy Buffet better (it's not quite the same buffet, but ok). Even so, she always has her plate piled way high. 

Service was very good- it's a team, here. Greetings once inside and upon exiting as well. Everything was clean and in order. Clean plates were replenished for the busy lunch time crowd. Dirty plates were promptly picked up, too. There is a "wasted food"  charge, too; well, signs are posted, anyway. FYI, gift cards are sold here.  

I would go here again. Next time, I will focus one plate entirely on the sushi station.

Yes, this all-you-can-eat buffet has a larger sushi section, but it's still buffet quality sushi.  Rubbery and cold with hardened up rice.

Other than the sushi, it's typical asian buffet fare.  Chicken wings (greasy and overloaded with lemon), beef and broccoli (salty), egg rolls, lo mein, etc.

If you are really craving sushi I suggest going to a regular AYCE sushi place.  Which is not to say there is anything wrong with buffets, but that the sushi here isn't anything special.

I went to Makino a few weeks ago with 2 friends who live in Vegas.

Overall the food was ok.  The sushi did not have descriptions or names on the sneeze guard so I had a hard time picking pieces not really knowing what they were.

To me the whole point of going to a sushi buffet is to try new things. I did that, I just don't know what they are!

It used to be better - I feel like the quality has gone down and the food is more Americanized. I felt slightly sick for the rest of the day after my lunch here. When I was a kid going to Makino was always the highlight of my trip to Vegas - I would love getting all kinds of weird sushi, roe, and other things that I couldn't even describe. Now they have pretty standard rolls (and no eel - my favorite). The miso, udon, and ramen were all very good. Their tempura is light and not too greasy. I like all the salads they have and their fried chicken was surprisingly good. The desserts all look disgusting but they always have - except the green tea ice cream, gotta save room for that!!

I would go back still because it's a family tradition and because it's still a good value. But it's definitely gone downhill.
Plenty of food (cooked and sushi) and great service. I definitely will be coming back! They are always busy so make sure to get there early.

This place is amazing!! Walk in, great atmosphere, and LOTS of variety. Plates are a very good size! Sushi, sushi, sushi EVERYWHERE! And not just "sushi", QUALITY sushi! Love this place. Coming back every Las Vegas trip.

If you are looking for lots of choices on Sushi and Warm Entrée dishes than this is your place. You can choose from literally 20 or more types of rolls. This is a buffet atmosphere, so you go get your own food. There is also dessert and my only wish is that the chocolate fountain had Warm chocolate in it.

Loved this buffet. Took my family here and they had high praises. Food was fresh and there was a lot of variety of choices to pick from. Their sushi is good and for a buffet that's hard to come by. We came here for lunch, but wouldn't mind coming back for dinner since we love seafood. I liked their noodle bar where you pour what kind of soup u want in the bowl. I love udon soup and I'm glad they have this. I wouldn't mind if they get pho too. Overall the buffet is awesome.

Every single time I've gone here has been an excellent choice for dinner. The service has always been good and the food primo! Everything from the sushi to the the dumplings to the poke is great! I think think is so far the best all you can eat Japanese seafood. Just the overall experience is a 5 star!

I always come here for dinner whenever i am in town for a getaway.  This sushi buffet is pretty good in quality and provides a good selection.  The fish portion is pretty big and they also serve sashimi tuna, octopus and yellow tail (i think).  The wait is usually around 30-40 minutes if you come on a weekend.  The buffet seems to wind down after 8:30pm so come early for dinner.

I have noticed that they don't serve raw oysters and cold crab legs any more (they do serve steamed crab legs and fried oysters instead).  I do enjoy their hand rolls as they are made to order.  The ramen is also good too.

I am very confused honestly how this place has such good reviews, and maybe I came on an off day and they secretly hired all new chefs that had no idea how to make anything properly.  I was so excited to come here, I have yet to find a buffet I really like, but the reviews seemed great! The pictures lured me to this establishment, I was ready to experience gluteny at its finest. 

 So we park and the parking lot is packed which is not surprising on a Sunday at lunch time.  When we walk in it's a pretty cramped bustling atmosphere, and our table they walk us to is connected to another parties table. Slightly awkward, but I'm not hear for ambiance I'm here to eat!   My first plate I made for myself was ok, not amazing but not awful, the items on my plate were from the sushi bar directly next to hand rolls.  I also had some fried squid which was decent.  It all went downhill from there.  The nigiri was a hot mess! The rice was way to wet, and the fish on most rolls was not proportionality cut, and was done so very sloppy.  The long row of rolls all looked better than they tasted.  I spit out a lot of food.  Also I noticed the potential for so much cross contamination since there was not enough tongs per item.  Also for hand rolls only at dinner do the offer the irkura hand roll.

In the hot section other than the calamari I tried the beef with mushrooms and onions. Most of the beef was overcooked from sitting under the heat lamp, making it so tough.  The shrimp tempura was soggy, and the rest of the tempura was just a trough of sadness.  I tried the ramen, the guy putting together did it a bit sloppy, and was trying to hit on the woman behind me at the same time.  He was a multi tasker...The noodle was very thin I prefer it curly and thick, the meat was tender, the broth was better than the box kind, but still missing a soul.  The sukiyaki meat was actually very nice, the noodle overcooked.  No crab legs anywhere at lunch, which I can understand Its cheaper.

The dessert area was a joke, it tasted like a bunch of dollar store mixes thrown together rather than anything of quality or from scratch.  Lots of artificial flavors, and calories that were not worth it.  The flan was the only decent thing there.  I saw no creme brule, that must also be a dinner item.

All in all, I just don't get the appeal of this place, it cured me of ever hoping to find a buffet that is worth my money.  Food that sits out, starts to change in texture, and quality.  I'll just stick to all you can eat like Gens if I have a deep urge to eat that much asian food in a sitting. At least then I know it is made to order, thus fresh.

Surprisingly so good for a sushi buffet!
You cannot expect A+ quality fish here, but it's good enough for me.

FOOD:
-Enough variety from sushi, rolls, poke, miso soup, udon, ramen, fried rice, tempura, yakisoba, short ribs, teriyaki, clams, crabs, desserts (creme brûlée my fav!)
-Majority of the food tasted very good compared to other ayce sushi restaurants.

PRICE:
-$29.99 for adults, about half price for children (depending on their height)
-Can't beat this price for a buffet in Vegas!

SERVICE:
-Very attentive; switched our plates & refilled our drinks as soon as we were finished
-Get here early! Started forming a line at 5:45pm on a Saturday
-Parking was also packed by 5:30pm

I will def return when I come back to the area. 
Left with such a happy, fulllllll stomach :')
Nothing special.  It's just a sushi/Chinese/Korean buffet.  If you are really hungry and don't want to wait 40 min for your meal, this is a good choice for it!

I have been going to Makino for the past 12 years, and every time I go back I remember why I never got tired of this place. I'm greeted like family, the staff is friendly, and the food is great. Their sushi might not be prepared with the most expensive fish cuts (but so is the check), but they offer a good variety of rolls, and it all tastes great. The salads section of the buffet is equally rich and fresh. On top of sushi, they offer many other Sea Food and Asian cuisine dishes, a variety of soups, and a nice selection of mini desserts, complimented by a chocolate fountain and exotic flavored ice cream (green tea, red beans flavor and others). The best local sushi buffet.

Plenty of choices...Like orgy for all the Asian food together- there is Korean short ribs, fried rice, chow mein, Sushi...etc. But at $27.95/person for dinner, there are lots lots of sushi AYCE, Chinese AYCE, Korean AYCE at lower price or better quality in Las Vegas.

My family's been going to Makino since it opened, it is our go-to place whenever we're craving sushi. Their sushi is not -the- best, I admit, but it's not the worst either. I really like the variety in their buffet menu. Their salads and cold dishes is actually my favorite. I like getting a big pile of edamame to nibble on as my appetizer. I usually ignore half of the hot dishes since I can eat most of them at home (like fried rice and yakisoba) but I have tasted them and they are pretty good. I love that they added ramen as well. Their desserts are a hit or miss sometimes. My favorites throughout the years are the thin almond cookies and their creme brulee. There were times that they didn't have both which is why I deducted a star (lol) because some of their dessert items are a little mediocre, sorry. 

But of course they're known for their seafood and 90% of the time it's fresh and delicious. However, the 10% of the time, the crab legs were flavorless and thin and the oysters didn't taste fresh. Sushi and sashimi, in my opinion, have always tasted pretty good. The only thing that saddens me is that they stopped serving salmon sashimi slices :( 

Service has always been A+. Drinks were always refilled and waitresses are easy to call on.
I was told about this place by a local.  Very good food and fresh. The staff is excellent.

This is a sushi and seafood lovers delight!  They have a variety of sushi's, from fresh fish to egg to eel, name it, they have it.  They had quiet a few seafood dishes including crab legs (all you can eat) to Japanese tempura to Chinese food...a great smorgasbord of all you can eat, unlimited, seafood n sushi and everything else.

I went here after the outlet mall one closed. I tried lunch and I was disappointed it was no where as good as the other location.  There was less sushi and the quality wasn't as good.   The pros are the udon and ramen but I went for the sushi and was disappointed.

Great place to bring friends and family!! First time vist with my husband, his parents and our kids (ages 3 and 1). Very clean, not crazy busy and child friendly. The sushi was delicious. Lots a variety and freshly made. There is also hot dishes that my children enjoyed. I ate both sushi and hot dishes and was very impressed. Dessert was wonderful also. Kid friendly environment and service as very attentive. We will definitely be back!

This is one of the greatest buffets I've ever been to :) They had a great selection of sushi, seafood (including crab legs), some meats, my miso soup..etc..   Everything I put on my plate I loved.  This place is not that close to the strip, but it was worth the drive!  I will definitely hit this spot again when I'm in Vegas.

NEVER AGAIN! I won't be returning to this buffet ever. Starting with what's important, the food. I remember the food being really good (hot and fresh) at the outlet location, everything was cold and soggy here. The fish/sushi was okay. We got in around 815 and asked if we were okay having only an hour to eat as they close at 930. We obliged and then started eating. About 915 they announced on the intercom that they were closing. 920 they interrupted our meal and asked that we start paying for the bill as they need to close down the register. It was rather annoying, but gave our CC and continued eating. Then at 925 they turned off majority of the lights and employees started leaving already?!? First of all, I have never been to a restaurant where they kick you out by close time. At most places, if you're in eating, they let you finish your meal, but just stop letting others in. And then on top of that, turn off the lights on your customers? Such trash. Won't be surprised when this location closes.

I don't think this place is necessarily bad, it's just not for me. It needs to be remodeled desperately. It is very run-down looking and it needs a new AC system. It is so busy, people are being herded in and out like cattle, making it very stuffy. Expect a wait, always. We waited an hour. 
I will say you definitely get the bang for your buck. It is extremely reasonable for a buffet/AYCE style sushi, but there's something about eating mass produced sushi in a warm environment that makes me kind of nauseas. If you're on the same page as me, they have cooked food as well. I couldn't get past eating raw food in this environment so I opted for that. 
They have beer and wine available which is a plus! (Not part of buffet pricing). There is also a guy that makes hand rolls of your choice and it is delicious. The hand roll guy and chocolate fountain were my favorite parts of this interesting dining experience.

Holy cow this might be my new favorite buffet. Really delicious meats incl super moist and flavorful teriyaki chicken, beef teriyaki/kalbi, Japanese hamburger steak (yummy sauce!). Great selection of sushi. Sukiyaki!!! Be sure to call ahead and make a reservation; people line up 30 mins before opening for dinner!

If you've ever been to a Todai. It's similar except they have more sushi selections. You can stuff yourself silly at this place. It's just ok food. It's not as good quality as a real sushi restaurant. But right in the middle. I would say average. I've eaten here a couple of times with family and it's been alright. Not much to expect from buffet food but a lot better than the ones I've been too in L.A.

I've visited this restaurant several times over the past 10 years or so and wanted to introduce it to my fiancee.

Pros:
I  can say with confidence that the quality and variety has remained very consistent over the years since my first visit.

There are so many items from which to choose that just about anyone should be pleased with the selection.
This is a Japanese restaurant, so the focus is on sushi and sashimi.
However, they regularly have several other raw and cooked seafood items, a few items from the grill, interesting salads, soups, etc.
The variety and quality of the desserts is above par compared to other sushi restaurants or Asian buffets we've tried.

Most of all, this is a very good deal for a Las Vegas buffet.
The best evidence for this is the line that begins to form outside the restaurant at least 20 minutes before they open for dinner, even on weeknights.
They've raised there price for dinner only a couple of dollars over the past 10 years. With drinks, tax, and tip our tab came to about $35 per person.

Cons:
Arriving at the restaurant even just 30 minutes after opening can result in a rather long wait for a table because the demand for the dinner buffet well exceeds their capacity to seat people.

The quality of the nigiri, maki, and sashimi is definitely good but not outstanding.
No real surprise, though, as this is, after all, sushi for the masses.

They used to have raw oysters on the line, which was one of the principal reasons why I became a fan of this restaurant. However, they have now been replaced with fried oysters, which were still a treat.

Photo Design:
by Billie Z.

Went there the other day for lunch and I have to say I was impressed with their selection of sushi, hot apps, and soup.  The atmosphere is comparable to a buffet during peak times, little bit of a wait to be seated and then the usual slow go to get to your choice of food.  Overall the food is good.  Only thing that I would suggest to management is more tongs for each plate of Sushi.

Since Todai has been closed, I search for another all you can eat sushi to satisfy my craving. When it comes to sushi buffet, the quality I expect to be standard and average. Makino is good, not best but good. 

I went for lunch and there was no sashimi, which I'm not sure whether they offer it for dinner or not offer at all. I'm not a big fan of rice, so nigiri won't do me any good. Makino has tons of rolls, I mean tons. They offer so many kinds of rolls, occupy the whole section on the right hand side. Their rolls are good but the rice portion is too much for me.

Hot food and cooked food is average. They don't offer so many hot dishes and as of I'm writing this review a week after I left Vegas, I had no impression or memory about their cooked dishes. 

So overall, Makino has good price and good variety of sushi and roll. They pride for their hand roll made to order but again, too much rice and big roll for me. They are packed on lunch and I can't imagine how it will be for dinner.

This is the best all-you-can-eat sushi buffet I have eaten at! I am a huge fan of sushi so this place was heaven for me. There is still plenty of other food here if you aren't a fan of sushi, but you won't be getting your money's worth. Not only do they have your standard sushi, but they have sushi rolls as well. They prepare the rolls and you take however many pieces you want. 

The non-sushi food is pretty good as well. If you are a big fan of Japanese food, you will be satisfied, but if not, you should stay away. Their dessert selection is above average for a buffet. They had creme brule which was yummy, and they had real ice cream. None of that soft-serve stuff, but real hand-scooped ice cream in many different flavors. I tried the green tea ice cream and it was delicious!

The cost was around $25 for dinner. We went on a weekday, so it might be a few dollars more for the weekend/holidays. 

Although it is off the strip, if you don't mind the drive or need a break from the "traditional" Vegas buffets, you should definitely give this a try!
Best Asian buffet in town. Its just a little expensive. Overall its great food, its just a little too crowded. I hope they open another restaurant in a different location.

We went for the AYCE buffet on a Wednesday afternoon. They were located on S Decatur Blvd/W Flamingo Rd in the Renaissance Center West in Las Vegas.

Monday-Thursday lunch $16.95
Monday-Thursday dinner $25.95
Fri, Sat, Sun, and holidays lunch $17.95
Fri, Sat, Sun, and holidays dinner $26.95
Drinks not included

They did not allow photos of the sushi on the buffet which seemed odd.  Forks, spoons, and napkins were near the plates.  Chopsticks were already on the tables.

There were large bowls of wasabi and ginger near the sushi.  There were 2 bowls of soy sauce, but they were watery.  There were little dishes for the wasabi and ginger.

I liked the chicken wings, shrimp tempura and the Manila clams.  The sushi was okay.

They had a small chocolate fountain with fresh fruit and marshmallows. They also had ice cream.   I liked the green tea cake.  I didn't care for the flan.

I would come back for weekday lunch.
Every time we are in Vegas, we always eat here.  I think it's a great price for the selection.  And the have sashimi where most places don't offer it at all.  Never disappointed & always fresh.

I'm surprised to see the mixed reviews for this place. And I'm surprised people thought Todai was better than Makino's.. I don't know, maybe Todai in the Bay Area is just really shitty, cause Todai isn't good at all around here. Anyhow, my friends and I wanted to go to Makino since we knew it was a sushi/Japanese buffet. Also, my boyfriend and I had tried Makino's in Honolulu and it wasn't that great, but his parents mentioned that the one in Vegas was a lot better.

First of all, I thought the quality of food was actually very good considering it is a buffet. Also, the restaurant was very clean while we were here and the service was also very attentive and friendly. We never had to ask for refills or for our plates to be taken away. 

Makino offers sushi, hot food (fried rice, grilled meats, tempura, fish, soup), a salad bar with like eight different types of salads, and then a dessert area. A lot of people seem to think the sushi quality isn't that great. Yeah, it's not GREAT sushi, but I think for a buffet, the quality is pretty high. And even though the rolls are kind of repetitive , they're all really big.  The salad bar has some really good salads - my favorite was the cucumber seaweed salad.  Then on to the hot food, tempura was good and they also had White Ba-Sa fish which was very tasty.

Last but not least, the dessert area has yummy desserts. they have fresh fruit, a chocolate fountain , crepes, ice cream, and different types of mini cakes/pastries.  OH, and they have AMAZING green tea ice cream. On top of that, my favorite was the creme brulee.

Bottom line.. I think people are reviewing this place kind of harshly. Come on, it is a buffet and you're only paying around $25.00. If the food here was at a restaurant and you paid a la carte for each item, then I would have given them a lower rating. But being a buffet, I think the food here is very good.

On this recent trip to Makino I was disappointed, we arrived about an hour before closing time and everything looked OK but the cooks seemed more interested in cleaning up and getting out of there. The food was not being changed or refilled so everything was warm but not hot except the Miso and other soups. No fresh items were added to the Sushi section when we were there. Service was average for drinks and plate removal but the cute waitress kept haranguing us to pay the bill. Well F**k that I'll pay when I'm ready to leave, and you guys are not even closed yet and I'm still eating. Some days it not worth the price and today was that day.

This is my new "go to" for all you can eat sushi. The hot food is delicious, the dessert is amazing, and the sushi is plentiful. 

It is worth getting in line before they open to be the first one to get the fresh food!

I first visited Makinos when some friends of mine took me there for lunch at the Outlet mall. Though this location is now closed, my husband and I made a visit to the one on Decatur. The atmosphere wasn't quite as nice as the one at the outlet mall but the food was still very good. Las Vegas buffets can get quite pricey, but this was very affordable. My husband and I love sushi and have eaten at many different places, and we really enjoyed eating at this particular restaurant. The only slight downside is it's family style dining, so you'll be sitting quite close to strangers, especially when it is busy. But they have many other food options besides sushi, which makes it a friendly place for everyone to eat, for those who do not like raw fish. If you're looking for a casual sushi restaurant with good prices and good food, this is the place for you.

Makino's was...alright. The sushi rolls were decent, some nice flavor and the rice wasn't stale; of course, all the sushi rolls tasted just about the same.......but they weren't bad! they were..decent.

Lots of vegetarian options, yummers seafood pancake, and a chocolate fountain! and green tea ice cream that tasted like strawberry ice cream (hmm..interesting....) oh, and okra! (though not in the same sentence as green tea ice cream lol) I haven't encountered very many restaurants that serve okra, let alone okra done well; so, okra, chocolate fountain, seafood pancake, all equating to 3 stars. Makino is one of those restaurants that you don't take new people to or opt to go to yourself, but you won't decline when your friends suggest it (friends, you don't need to suggest it...)

We came here for Christmas Day dinner.  We did this three years ago.  We thought it would be fun to go to the M, but when we arrived, the line was insanely long.  We then went to the Rio and that was just as worse.  We then went to Makino and had no problem getting a table, however it was 8:30 that time.  We arrived just before 5 and there was already a line that snaked around their entrance.  When we reached the front, they gave us a table in the back corner.

It was very cozy in there on this day.  The line snaked around the buffet line and the sushi area and then down one aisle right in front of our table.  My parents got in line, but we stayed at the table.  My dad brought us plates just in case they ran out...LOL!  When the line seemed to get shorter, my parents were at the end of the sushi so we cut in front...lol!  This place is Japanese food heaven!  You can get handmade rolls as well, which seemed to hold up the line.  I grabbed another plate and decided to fill both up since I did not want to stand in line again.  Only got a couple inaris, but no other sushi.  My favorite were the ribs!  They had just come out of the oven and were so tender!  I also liked the spicy short ribs...they had a little kick to them!  Great kale salad!

This was the last buffet for the year!  And we have a new tradition now if we come back during Christmas.

This place is pack with a lot people. At first I was impress at their selections, then I realize it was the same thing over and over just with one diff ingredient. I ate a few  role pieces and it was ok. It wasn't bad. Then the food made me feel uncomfortable. The hot food was below average, like the chicken and beef teriyaki. Then the ramen and udon was average. I couldnt tell the diff between that and the stuff u buy at grocery store. After some eating, I felt really uncomfortable and then I remember all the warnings I heard about Asian buffets and where they possibly could buy their food from- China. No offense, but there's a lot of rumors and reports of adulterated on the internet  on food from China. If I had to do this over again, I would avoid eating Asian buffets all together. I would prolly not come back here again. Sorry if I offend the people who own this place. Just honest opinion.

We loved the selection and quality of food at this location. We have been to other ayce japanese sushi restaurants, and this place beats other places by far. Really attentive waitresses and fresh sashimi was served during lunch hours. We also loved their tonkatsu ramen. It was one of the better ramen we had at a buffet. Price was reasonable at around $60 for 2 adults/2 kids during lunch hours. I would keep coming here on my next trips to LV.

Ate here in thanksgiving day!! It was busy but nothing out of the ordinary. It wasn't our first choice but it was close to where we were and ended up being really great quality and satisfying! The sushi was fresh but by the time we left was not refreshed. I will keep this in mind when I'm back in town with friends if my usual AYCE sushi places are busy or closed.

It is a decent Asian type food buffet plus a pretty good sushi variety.  It gets 2 stars because the value for the price is not great.  The service was exceptional, but still not worth upgrading the stars due to the price.

Las Vegas has many AYCE sushi places.  Not many are a buffet.  Most are around $25.  Las Vegas also has many AYCE buffets specializing in Asian food.  Not many are $25, but they don't offer the variety of sushi Makino does.  Not far from here are better options for both at a much better value.  

I have been on a quest to try Makino for a couple of months after hearing about it and checking out the website.  A sushi buffet sounded interesting and I had read good things.  Since I was on the west side of town near Makino, I finally had my chance today.  It was crowded so I took that as a good sign.  

After paying like $30 for lunch, I expected a lot, being I've been to several of the AYCE sushi places, at least 9 in the 4 months I've lived in Las Vegas.  

The desert section looked great, and then there was some standard Japanese fare, like tempura shrimp, and some chicken dishes with fried rice and noodles.  Then there was the sushi area.  It wasn't nearly as majestic as the videos on the website make it seem.  There were many varieties of sushi and fresh fish, but most were just bland instead of the flavorful varieties I've experienced at the other AYCE places.  Most didn't have any additional sauces with them to compliment the flavor. The desert section was pretty good.  

As I mentioned above, service was excellent, but I will not be back.  Life's too short for bland sushi for the price that's more than many better sushi places.

Come here. I was confused for a little trying to figure out where this was since they used to have another location but this was the main focus and they ended up closing the other places. Came a little after they opened and seem to be busy. The sushi was fresh, seemed to be always stocked and clean. They had all types of sushi, Plus food. I stuck with the rolls and some of the basic warm food. Don't go much into the rest but everyone was into it . It was only about $20 and I'd say I ate $40-50 worth of food!

Absolutely ridiculous. Came here Sunday night, $30 per adult, half for children under 11 years and under 5ft. We walked in and said three adults and one child, they give us our check 5 min after our DRINK order and on the check they charged us for 4 adults. I explained to the waitress there was a mistake and she asked my little sister how old she was and she said 11. The waitress walked away, brought another woman out about 15 min later ( I'm assuming the manager) while the rest of the staff begin to give us odd stares. She comes out and asks how old my sister is and I say 11 then she asks her what year she was born, then drags her over to the front of the restaraunt to have her MEASURED embarrassing her in front of everyone. Needless to say we got the half off discount for her but this was so unnecessary. Also the food was mediocre. 4 people came out to $136.00 for seafood that's been sitting out all day. Never again! Creme brulee was bland, sushi tasted fishy, crab legs had no meat in them, gave us ice tea with an orange?
Music sucked and staff was rude

Aww so bummed. I haven't been here for lunch in a few years and came back today only to find out they no longer serve crab legs and creme brûlée anymore.  Maybe only dinner, but drat! I remembered the sushi rolls use to be pretty good.  The sushi rolls are pretty mediocre drenched in heavy mayo sauce. Service was great.  Just overall bummed about quality of food and the cut of two of the best items on the menu.
Great selection of sushi and crab legs are very good! For a seafood buffet very good. Seafood is better than most strip buffets.

We stumbled across this place when we visited Vegas and decided to hit up the outlets.  It was about $18 per person for lunch on a weekday which is pretty decent considering it is a sushi buffet afterall.

Why the 5 stars?  I've been to other sushi buffets such as Todai, Vegas Seafood Buffet (in Glendale, CA) & Zen Sushi, etc.  The price at Todai is outrageous in comparison!!  My BF loaded up on the sushi which they were not skimpy at all.  They had Red Snapper, Tuna, Salmon, Octopus, Mackerel and a few others.  There were also a handful of rolls.  

I noticed a variety of salads including seaweed salad.  

On the other side of the sushi counter, there was the cooked foods counter.  You can choose from shrimp tempura, mixed vegetables tempura, udon w/ soup, chow mein, steamed mussels, etc.

There is also a dessert station with a chocolate fountain.  

What it lacks in selection, the quality of the food makes up for it!  Would definitely go back the next time we're in Vegas!!

Had to grow to extra hands to give this place 4 thumbs down. I've been searching for the BEST AYCE.  I still haven't found it.. This place was packed so we walked in thinking this food must be amazing. We ate a little and pushed it to the side. Then we tried to salvage the rest of our money by eating desserts. I gave 2 stars cause the server kept my coke full. Sorry makino wish i enjoyed your food..

Crowded, the food was okay but I don't think we will come back. The sushi was okay but come for lunch not dinner the cost is crazy for dinner for what you get. I just saw so many kids that I was afraid to for the food as not sure what was touched and what was not as it was so busy there were not people watching the desserts and bars to keep people straight (even the adults).

I ate here on June 04, 2015. The sushi rice was cold and it should be room temperature. The hot food was ok, but it was dry and the tilapia was too firm. I liked their salads and desserts. Nigiri suppose to have wasabi, but the sushi chefs didn't add any. It's not sushi if there is no wasabi in the nigiri. Service was good.

to me this place is about the same as Todai... japanese food, for americans! they do have a varity of selections, but mostly are to americans standard... not much of the real japanese stuff... 

went there once because some of my ABC friends really recommended it... but... i had better... so, will not go back again.

Oh my... I never thought I would find a buffet in Vegas that I would like but lo and behold... my brother brought me here and its amazing...
The sushi is so fresh and yummy and the fresh crepe bar can't be beat as well as the chocolate fountain =)
The green tea iced tea is different and refreshing...
We come here everytime we come to Vegas...

ahhh makino. a seafood buffet off the strip that serves sushi, crab, mini stuffed lobsters (giant shrimp), fondue, and chinese style buffet food. Sounds great considering whats on the menu, but none of the items seemed to tickle my taste buds. they were all decent, but nothing great. 

the service was nice. filled our drinks without us asking. there was a sign on the sushi window saying they charged 25 cents for all the uneaten rice from the sushi. but i dont think they really charge that. just to discourage people from eating sashimi without being full on rice. 

quality of the fish seemed a little old. felt like it was at room temperature which isnt a good thing. but none of us got sick. 

so i give this place a 3 star rating. they can work on more variety in desserts. more variety with the rolls. serve a little better quality fish in the sushi section.

My mom and I love to come here for brunch. The rolls are pretty good, especially for a buffet. The sushi can also be good if you're lucky, but just mediocre most of the time. No sashimi. Many of the cooked foods are good too, but I normally eat rolls and sushi. The dessert is also good. They serve ice cream, crepes, etc. They have a chocolate fountain too which I thought was pretty cool. Can't comment too much on the service since it is a buffet, but overall it's a good place to come if you're nearby. Not one of the best seafood buffets you'll probably find though.

Crowded. Unorganized set up in general including entry process(we had to wait outside for an hour). Food distribution utensils unsanitary. Servers made us get our own silverware. Bathrooms could use some cleaning. Food selection limited. Overall experience was sub-par

This is my first time and the quality is here.. very fresh and tasty! 
Came here with family and they got their grub on.. at least three plates each.. 
I got topped out at two and a half. 

Its a buffet place and I'm usually leery of places like this but this place is off strip so it's mostly locals. 

I'll be back next trip.

I came here with a big group of guys that love to eat. The sushi was fresh, the hand rolls were amazing, everything was off the hook just as good as Los Angeles food. I felt so spoiled because of the prices were about 20 bucks for a lunch buffet. The staff was accommodating and gave us a lot of good drinks. This place seems like a local spot to go to if you are in the Vegas area but not on the strip. I am totally going to bring my family here when we go to Vegas because the sushi is so darn good. We are from the Bay Area and eat sushi all the time and it's great to have somewhere else to eat at that's not in the bay. I would recommend the ramen and pretty much everything that's presented especially the hand rolls. There fish are sushi grade and they come in huge boxes very fresh.

Mediocore food factory.  Why anyone comes here with all the great buffets and AYCE sushi spots in Las Vegas is hard to comprehend.

Please don't spend your calories here.
Great buffet just off the strip. Fresh seafood and friendly staff. The food was constantly being added and my empty plates were constantly being taken away.

its a good idea for u guys to drive down here from the strip..just read all the positive reviews here..the one who post the negative ones are the picky eaters who compares this joint to R32 in downtown LA. the quality of sushi is good.. fresh..no fighting for tempura shrimp..they have this steak thing wrapped in bacon..real good..soup yum..i went for lunch..i remember going to dinner before too with the crablegs..oh yeah and Thrifty ice cream..oh soo good..next time i will go here for dinner..ima try to stick the crab legs in the chocolate fountain...

I was iffy about coming here but who would say no to an  all you can eat sushi buffet?
It was super crowded since it was a Sunday night on Labor Day weekend but the servers were on top of everything, especially with refills and taking empty plates out of the way. 
The cooked portion of the food was pretty good but the sushi? It's unnerving that sushi is just sitting out at room temperature. It would be fine if the pieces of sashimi were taken quickly but they weren't. I tried one piece of ahi and it was fine but my fiancé had a piece of yellowtail which he said tasted wrong. Now he's sitting in the bathroom puking his brains out. 
This place is over priced, small, and the desserts were a major disappointment. Either still frozen or flavorless. 
Won't be going back since I fear getting sick.

Been coming to Makino since I was a college student, on a budget. I would often head to Vegas for fun trips with girlfriends. Friends would recommend this place. This AYCE started at $16 per person and is now $17/pp for lunch buffet.

We still come here, as a matter of fact I brought my family and fiance here earlier in January of this year, and they had so much fun with the "hot foods" section. I think it is still a good deal. But one time my fiance got food poisoning. So, I do not know how fresh it really is. I would still come back, here, because it's so convenient near the outlets, but for $17/pp for buffet lunch, it could be a little steep. We'll see. It really is convenient though and pretty yummy. I like how there is a lot of selection, and there are  constantly people making the sushi, even though it's not authentic. (Lots of CALI rolls with toppings).

Came here for dinner, everything looked so delicious when walking in, especially when you are hungry. As I walked the food line, there wasn't much of a selection. The sushi was the best part for me until I saw an ant crawling on the counter. 

Snow crabs was the reason why the hubby wanted to eat here. I had a plate of it and I wasn't impressed. They over cooked their crabs. Most of them looked so dirty and you can barely break them, they were too soft. 

The fried rice and all that stuff were just mediocre. Dessert was bleh. Overall it's ok, if you're looking for a cheap buffet, then this is it. $30 per person for dinner.

Every time i go to Vegas, my family and i make it a point to go to this fantastic Japanese buffet. Being born and raised in Hawaii, i grew up around asian cuisines, so i know good sushi when i eat one! I sometimes fear to purchase sushi whilst in the mainland (or even europe) because i have had bad experiences, but this place never fails me. i always feel like such a fatty here, though....considering that i'll eat multiple sushi-filled platters and such. i always get seconds of anything w/unagi and masago. their combos are delicious! and don't forget dessert! (chocolate fountain, ice cream, crepes, just to name a few!). im a huge fan of soups also, so yay to them for having miso and udon! various types of tempura is also a plus! 

So if you feel like escaping the strip and eating at an affordable asian buffet, i would suggest Makino. i mean seriously...All you can eat sushi at a good price? yes, please!

Normally the words "sushi" and "buffet" together make me want to run to the bathroom and hurl.  Not the case with Makino.  I've eaten here a few times in the past few months and the quality of the food is excellent.

The sushi is always very fresh.  They have the best soy sauce.  They add some crushed red peppers and it gives it just a little kick.  All of the hot food is gourmet quality.  I haven't tried the desserts but they look great.  This has to be one of the best sushi buffet restaurants in Las Vegas, if not the western USA.

Very good sushi for this price range. They put more fish in their sushis than I have ever seen. Very authentic Japanese restaurant with very attentive service. They don't have sashimi for lunch time though, but good enough!

Thought the food is ok nothing special. Kinda like a Todai. You have your rolls, sashimi, Chinese food, soups and alittle seafood(crab legs, clams). Would think the price would be about 9-10 dollars cheaper but it's Vegas.

I admit, I pretty much look down on restaurants off the strip or hotels because I don't know how bad they possibly could be to not be on the strip. I guess being a tourist makes me kind of ignorant of places sometimes. 

Makino is located on a typical town center you see anywhere, doesn't look too standout-ish, so you would've never guessed how good this place was. 

Once I walked in Makino, the staff made me feel at ease and were very welcoming. Walking up to the buffet was like heaven. And you wonder, 'Wow, all this sushi for only $25?!'; they had EVERYTHING: spicy tuna, eel rolls, california, etc. So many a la carte ones as well! My only problem with the sushi is that the rice isn't kept tight. If I poked lightly at a roll, the rice will fall apart easily.

They even have a chocolate fountain (thank God, someone has finally answered my prayers!) and a miso soup machine. Pretty awesome! Except the guy behind the dessert counter who refused to answer my question if there were any strawberries.

Went here for mother's day. To me, it was just OK. On the plus side, they have a lot of seafood choices. Fish, sushi, invertebrates, etc. All you can eat. The staff was attentive. The negative: $27.95/each for dinner, so with 5 of us eating, it came to just a little over $150 and some change. For my money and medium appetite, I would rather go to a nice, sit-down restaurant where I can order a decent $25 entree from a menu. Once a year at this place is good enough for me.
Best crab legs and all you can eat rest of food average though but still good place

I think this place is getting shorted on the reviews.  This is probably my fifth time here, albeit spaced out over a decade.  This food has always been high quality.  And the price is definitely right.  And consistent, as I would have given this place 4 stars on every visit.

1.  Nigiri section isn't the largest, but there's about 8 selections.

2.  Plenty of rolls for those that want it.

3.  Hot food is good too.

4.  They have a ramen bar.

5.  The place is packed, and you do sit close together.  But I ask anyone, you come to an AYCE buffet for the atmosphere?

6.  It's all about the food, stupid.

7.  Yes, there's a lot of Mexicans making your food.  I will admit that this bothers me a little as it takes away from "authenticity", but Makino's has been around quite a long time now, and it's a successful business.  (Let's face it, if Japanese were preparing your food the buffet would be twice as expensive).  Reminds me of the dolts that preach Buy American! but spends their money at Wal-Mart because it costs less (can't have your cake and eat it too, folks).

8.  Therefore, for the value that you get here - 4 star food at a great price, Makino's is a top choice.

Been here a few times already and every time have been pretty pleasant. Not my most favorite buffet, but I still come when a friend wants to try it or needs a sushi and other items craving. 

I do like it when they have oysters! lol. I go crazy for it! 
Last nights visit wasn't my favorite though. The food seemed a little tasteless, especially the salmon. Had to spit it back out. We did sit at the very very back where all the employees go in and out from the kitchen, but it was a full house so I understand. Everything else wasn't too bad. The sushi, the desserts, the soups were all decent.

Side note, the desserts aren't too fresh. Some are still frozen when placed out to grab. This is a small buffet. A bit overpriced but that's because they have seafood.


The employees that all work there are amazing. They are all on the roll with switching out the sushi and putting out fresh ones when its running low. Even the women who were taking our plates were quick and came to always ask how we were doing. The girl at the dessert section asked if we wanted ice cream when you usually have to ask. 

I feel like a total oinker when I leave though. Always have to try everything...
Fuh...

Ohana come to Vegas from Hawaii. Looking for a great AYCE Sushi place. Found it here at Makino.
Great Taste. Quality. and Variety. Ono. The Best 
AYCE Sushi. Go for dinner a lot more choices. Well worth the extra few dollars.
Aloha!!

if you are craving for fresh sushi and hand rolls with reasonable price and AYCE, this will be my favorite place to stop by.  My favorite hand roll is spicy tuna and crunchy shrimp tempura.  Sea weed roll is very crunchy and smell roasted gives you very fresh crispy taste.
Lots of sushi to choose from.  They have sushi  you never see in most sushi buffets.  Love their selection of warm dishes as well as desserts.

It's not too often that I voice my disappointment, however, I felt like I should say something about my visit to Makino for lunch today. We went there because my son chose it for his birthday lunch. The lunch was $22 per person. This is about the same price as dozens of AYCE sushi places all over town. The variety and quality at Makino does not compare to other Sushi places we have been to. It is more like a cafeteria as far as seating goes. We had to ask people to move so we could get out of our tiny space! The sushi was just ok. The tempura shrimp was just ok. There was no sashimi, no poke. The food in general was lacking flavor.  For $22, there are so many other lunch options out there. I would have been happier with an $8 bowl of ramen! To sum it up; if you're looking strictly for quantity and don't mind the noise and cafeteria setting and are willing to sacrifice quality and variety, then this is your place. If not, just drive down the street and you'll find something better!
This place has gone downhill. The sushi was frozen and falling apart. The ahi seemed freezer burned. We'll be looking for a new sushi place after tonight.

Showed up around 1230 with a group of four and we were seated right away. Tons of options, some labeled, some not, which made sushi choosing that much more adventurous. at least I've gotten reasonably good at identifying the things I'm allergic to (oysters, scallops -- not that these things are that hard to identify), so I managed to eat without needing a follow up ER visit.

The tempura was fresh and the batter was light. If you're looking for sweet potatoes (my favorite deep fried and battered veggie), there's a white yam option. Or at least it tastes enough like a yam that that's what I'm calling it. The tempura dipping sauce is not the standard -- it's a little sweeter and tangier -- but I liked it well enough. I tried a bit of yakisoba and a bit of beef teriyaki. Both of those were also fine.

Red bean ice cream is among my favorite desserts, and theirs is quite fine. I stayed away from the chocolate fountain as there were too many unaccompanied children wandering around near it, and who knows what they're stuck into that fountain. The blueberry mousse was tasty, as were the sesame cookies.

All in all, a fine meal. I wouldn't pay the dinner price if the food quality/options are the same at dinner, but for lunch prices, it seemed a reasonable value.

Good food as usual. Great selection of Sushi and for dinner had the shrimp kabobs and shrimp tempura. The price is a bit higher for dinner at $26.95 a person but it's a good price for what you get.

Also, they have crab legs too but cold. If you want they can heat them for you, just ask someone behind the counter.

Thanks.

Makino was my All-Star for like 10 years until AYCE Sushi bars started to get more attention.  Now that I have something to compare Makino to, I personally think it is sort o' getting played out.    Even though, this Godzilla of a sushi buffet will never get less than five as long as I'm yelping.  The extensive selection on sushi, fried foods, crab legs and dessert is still top notch.  I was deflowered by Makino in the aspect of sushi.  Makino will always be my first!

This is a *All You Can Eat* buffet, and great place to bring a large crowd for a small decent price. I usually eat at night so prices are $20-$24 never paid so I'm assuming lol. Never experienced a long wait time but it is always busy weekday or weekend. 

Atmosphere is pretty busy,tables are cluttered which you literally are too close to another party which I find pretty awkward. Service is not bad at all, refills are very prompt which is awesome for a busy restaurant.

Buffet line is pretty decent, a lot of random sea food choices. If you are planning to bring someone that has never ate raw fish or sushi this wouldn't be an example for a perfect sushi. Rice for the nigiri falls off which should be sticky, I had other better sushis. I do not memorize the full buffet line but you can get crab legs, oysters, clams, friend shrimp, plenty of sushi, soups, and dessert. Desserts are bomb, usually get the green tea ice cream.

Parking is decent many stalls to find since it also is near other stores and restaurants. 
I rate this store a 4 due to the noise level and cluttered tables.

Whenever I eat seafood/sushi somewhere that's not really close to the ocean, I'm pretty skeptical. Needless to say, I was even more apprehensive since we were in the middle of the desert.

I've been here a couple of times now, and the interior is always clean but it never gets too busy. Good place for a large group.

Buffet sushi is also usually not the freshest, and there was no exception here. The sashimi cuts in particular were kind of gross-looking. The crab legs and oysters also weren't that fresh.

On the plus side, there were many types of nigiri, and even more types of rolls (though most of them were modifications of the basic variations). There's also a whole side with plenty of hot foods, salads, and soups. 

The dessert section is particularly impressive, with a chocolate fountain!

It's basically a better version of Todai but also more expensive - I don't really think it's worth the price, especially considering there are so many buffet options in Vegas. When it comes to seafood, especially, it's got to be very fresh, otherwise it's just bad - there's not really an in between.

Good variety of food, but not the freshest. Unless you're super hungry, probably better to just go to a regular sushi place.
Nice of him to come by and check up on me. Told him great job and hope to be back again.  He smiled as hard to understand his accent voice.

Sushi variety is great. Crab legs may be all you can eat but it is served cold and the butter is actually butter flavored oil. The shrimp were overcooked and rubbery. The shoyu ramen was okay but the noodles were more like what I get in a ramen noodle package however the broth had good flavor.
Holy crapola, you do not have enough room in your belly for all the deliciousness you'll want to consume here. Prep your belly and yoga pants folks cause this place is going to push it to the limit.
Great all you can eat Sushi and other Japanese food. I'm from SoCal so will definitely try their Irvine restaurant!
Is the best sushi buffet in Las Vegas but I suggest to open one in Henderson Nv. Especially in Green valley district.

Came here on Wednesday right after it opened. No wait at all but the restaurant fills up pretty fast considering it is a weekday. The food selection was pretty good. Rice to fish ratio on sushi is great, not a big ball of rice. Rolls selection was good too. And they keep refilling very fast. They also serve salads and hot food like tempuras and fried rice. 

I really like the make to order hand rolls and noodle station. They also have ice cream, desert and fruits. Soda is included in price but not hot tea or juice. 

Considering the price, it is a great place to eat. I don't expect to get top quality when they only charge like 20 bucks a head and give you a load of good quality food to choose from. The service is also good as well. Dirty plates get pick up very fast and I never needed to ask for a drink refill.

Worst sushi I have ever had.  Bar none.  
Not a single roll was good. 

The rice was dry.  The flavors within each roll clashed.  The asparagus was undercooked.  The cucumber was hard as though it wasn't ripe for eating.  The sauces were flavorless.  The presentation of the rolls looked as though a bunch of random ingredients were mixed together.  The fish was the only thing on each roll worth eating. 

Even the sashimi was bad: octopus sliced so thick it was an unpleasant chore to eat it.  

Service, fantastic; dessert, good; ambiance, fine -- but nothing can make up for the fact that this is a somewhat spendy sushi buffet and the sushi was horrible.  I wasn't even there on an off night; it was Saturday at 6pm.  

Any other buffet in town that has sushi as a side-station would have been better than this place.  And I could have gotten three great, fresh rolls at any other sushi place in town for what I paid to have an awful, dry, mishmash of garbage at this place.

Total disappointment.

Makino's claim to fame is its AYCE sushi lunch and dinner buffets.  Prices for lunch and dinner vary depending on the day of the week (Mon-Thurs:  $15.95 lunch/$24.95 dinner; Fri, Sat, Sun, Holidays:  $16.95 lunch/$25.95 dinner).  The buffet line offers a wide variety of nigiri and rolls; however, it also has a tempting array of salads, hot dishes like tempura shrimp and vegetables, miso soup and udon, and desserts.  Makino does have its flaws.  The sushi rice is not nearly prepared to the exacting standards of better/higher end sushi restaurants.  Construction of its nigiri and rolls is impacted by a seeming lack of the appropriate amount of moisture and stickiness of the rice, which has a tendency to be a bit crumbly.  Also, hot foods, depending on turnover, get overcooked, tough, or soggy, in the case of the tempura-fried vegetables, due to spending too much time in steam trays on the hot line.  However, these shortcomings are more than offset by the Makino's sushi variety and its generous cuts of better than average quality fresh fish and other seafood.  Really, who eats sushi for the rice?   

I love sushi.  While I wouldn't want to eat it every day, I definitely enjoy getting my feed on for the stuff...almost to the point of discomfort.  That said, I don't just eat any sushi.  I do have some standards for quality and selection.  Therefore, Makino on Decatur has been my go-to stop for decent quality sushi at a very fair price.  For your best bang for your buck, I recommend doing them for lunch.

I don't know. Ridiculous wait time, you're practically sitting on top of the neighboring tables and a bit spendy for what it is. Plus, rude idiots elbowing everyone around them to get the last (or first) piece of who-the-hell-cares. 

And yet, they have a chocolate fountain. 

So I'll probably go again, especially if someone else is paying. Plus it's in the same strip mall as my favorite place EVA!!! (The Fat Greek, baby!) in case I can't wait any damn longer for a table at Makino.
A large selection buffet with both Asian and American styled food. A good value if you're hungry at $28.00 per person.

Arrived for late lunch at 2:30pm and was told that all food will be removed at 3pm and what food was in warmers is all the food that is left. Decided to return for dinner ($10 more) when it reopens at 5:30pm. Showed up at 5:20pm and there was a long line outside already. They got every seated quickly at 5:30 which was impressive.  They had a good selection of sushi/sashimi which tasted ok to me--my wife said it was real good. of all the food I sampled, I really like the fried shrimp, stir fried shrimp, and crunchy tempura.  The $29.99 per person is good for the selection of food and all you can eat. I wasn't real hungry when I got there so I was looking for really tasty food. I found enough tasty food to say I got a good dinner. The grilled chicken and baked fish I won't say was good. The BBQ rib may have killed my tastebuds. I think BBQ ribs and Chinese/Japanese food didn't work well for me.  Cheiko (waitress)was great at refilling our drinks, bringing napkins, and taking our empty plates-- she gets 5 stars.  They charge extra for drinks which was unusual for a buffet/all you can eat place. I will return but will skip the BBQ ribs and stick to seafood.

Normally, I really don't like Asian buffets like this at all. So, I have a really hard time deciding..do I like it? Granted, I still -don't- like Asian buffets overall. But, I would have to say that Makino is probably the prized gem of all Oriental Buffets in Las Vegas--at the same time, the experience and food that I encountered was average.

Ambiance: 3 - For an oriental buffet, most of which are small..Makino presents a pretty large and spacious serving area and seating space. Though, the seats can get a bit overcrowded and it can be hard walking through aisles when the place is full! 

Inside, it's pretty casual--I mean, it is a buffet after all! 

Service: 4 - The service received was quick and responsive. Our server was attentive and patient with my (rather rowdy) family hah! She was always there to take away our plates and bring us more water. Our table was always pretty clean! She deserves a gold star!! 

Food: 3 - The only food thats worth eating at Makino is clearly the seafood. Though, it might not be the best, if you're there it's still pretty good! For the sushi, obviously, there are way better, fresher places for the fish. I personally do not recommend it, but a few rolls are worth a try if you happen to find yourself at Makino! 

What I do recommend eating is crab legs and oysters (raw). Naturally, this is what everyone is here for!! And they don't disappoint--especially with their (what I consider) "king-sized" cups of butter for crab dipping! I was just there for crab legs and oysters. Hell, I was good for the night because that's all I needed! 

//Note: the crab legs were served warm when I was there! 

Another thing that was pretty nice was their desserts! I'm in love with desserts and found it cute and party-like that they had a chocolate fountain and fresh strawberries, along with their selections of cake and ice cream. Yeah, I found the diversity of dessert nice, but it still tasted average :/ maybe next time it'll be better! 

If all you like at oriental buffets are crabs and oysters, your life will be complete! Fill your butter cup and chow down!

Ate there for the first time this past weekend, and it was great. Never would have expected the choices available at an all you can eat place like this.  The crab legs were an excellent addition. Was in a sushi coma as I waddled back home.

Makinos is good on some things and not others.  They have improved on their sushi however they still use a LOT of sauce on them.  I would much rather have the sauce in a squeeze bottle and let me put it on myself OR have them make the same roll with and without the sauce for those that don't want it.  Not every sushi roll needs sauce.  Their apps, salads and hot entrees are typically VERY good and a nice variety.  Service is never an issue here and they are very friendly and always re filling my drink and cleaning off my plates.  

Is this place the best? No. But it's far from being the worst.  It's definitely a little bit above average in quality/food.  I go back on occasion but that's about it.

I asked for my money back!  The fish was rubbery.  The roll I ate tasted like a piece of carpet with mayonnaise on it.  The chow mein had a disturbing spice (?) in it.  The chicken skewer looked to have been sitting there for four days.  The locals seem to love this place.  That being said, one of them sitting next to me was eating her sushi with a fork.  You're better off getting a fish sandwich at a fast food restaurant.  Your gut will not like this food.

Honestly. No idea why reviews are so low at this joint. The sushi served is on par with any casual dining sushi establishment  out there. No it's not on par with Nobu or other  $75+ sushi establishments on the strip but it's not trying to be. Are the people leaving bad reviews seriously expecting the same quality? I filled myself on two plates of rolls. The tuna and salmon are fresh and delicious. They have a hand roll station that does made to order hand rolls. The spicy tuna was my favorite. I also had made to order tonkotsu ramen and it honestly was a lot better than my expectations. No Monta but for a Buffett establishment, I happily gobbled down the ramen. Tried some of the other things like gyoza, shrimp tempura and some classic Asian Buffett fare such as green muscles with cheese. Other than the shrimp tempura which is bomb, the none sushi foods were lackluster. Didn't care much for the desserts, but I was here for a sushi fill and it hit the spot!

They have great sushi rolls, sashimi & crab.  You will definitely get your $ worth.  The fish is good quality for a buffet as well as the sushi rice.  A plus when it comes to buffet places.  They constantly make the sushi so it seems very fresh.

The hot stuff is pretty mediocre as well as the desserts. They have a chocolate fountain, however they rarely refill the sticks. Also they have great ice-cream, but I had to chase someone down to get it (you can't get it yourself).  Also they have shaved ice-but nothing like asain/Hawaiian shaved ice.  Blocky chips of ice with yr choice of high-fructose corn syrup color! :) You'll also have to flag someone down for that as well.  

Other than that, they staff is friendly & quick. They don't pressure you or stare you down if you eat massive amts of sushi, sashimi & crab (which I go to these buffets for...the good expensive stuff...lol).  Loved it! Only Loved the green tea ice-cream & brulee in the dessert section, they nd to work on the dessert menu a bit more. Didn't like any of the hot dishes, pretty average.

I wasn't expecting much as the one in Hawaii is awful, I was pleasantly surprised!  The sushi and fish is not the highest of quality but decent.  The service was pretty good, prompt and attentive.  High value for the price you pay.

The flying fish eggs and salmon roe was the best sushi, they don't skim on these.  Avoid anything with the squid, it's cut too thick and too chewy.  The green tea ice cream is a good touch at the end.

nice restaurant, all kind of sushi and salads 
the service is great
prices are a little high for lunch but for one a while it's ok.

Staff was great. The food was OK but not great. One thing that was quite bad was the steamed clams. Way too salty and that seemed like the only seasoning. If they had drained most of the water and thrown in a stick of butter and some garlic they'd be much improved.

We got there at 7 on a Friday night and were seated quickly, go figure.

Value ? I'm no Vegas buffet expert but I'd say below average value. Paid almost $50 at the Aria and felt OK about it. (Aria had better seafood but, as you might guess, not sushi selection).

Crab legs were moist and delicious!  Loved the shrimp tempura and fried oysters too.  Fresh hand rolls made to order were the freshest and best way to get good sushi, we went an hour before closing so the sushi already made looked like it was out for a bit.   Green tea ice cream was a great treat.  WAY BETTER IN VEGAS compared to Hawaii Makino Chaya.  I guess owners are brothers.
Food is plentiful, but low quality. Never again will I visit this restaurant again. People might disagree with me, but that's okay. You can stuff your face.

Solid sushi buffet if that is what you are looking for even though we are in the middle of a desert and 500 miles from the beach.   

They have a good selection of sushi, sashimi, hot plates, soups, and desserts.

We have been coming to this restaurant for 7 years and it seems the qualities and sekections are getting worse. I used to have seaweed salad every lunch time and good salad selections. But this time that the fishes were not fresh and no taste. No calamari no grilled steaks and no seaweed salad. It's a busy place for lunch and I think they are trying to save the money by cut down the cost. I will not go there again. It's very sad after you have been there for all these years and see the changes.

Arrived for dinner right at advertised opening time, but found a door sign saying they would be open a half hour later, so we waited in the parking lot.  Service was very good and most of the selection was also very good.  However, there were certain sushi dishes that were bland and the rice on others were not as moist as preferred.  Others such as octopus, shrimp, crab, and salad dishes were very good.   Suggest you call for start time and their senior rate to confirm.

Best Buffet I've ever been to!! The food is always warm, we ended up staying for two hours! Good thing there was no time limit! The food is the best, and the best for the price! Me and my family were just gobbling everything up! The bathrooms were also very clean, they have 2 big mirrors (one long one for both sinks and a body sized one)! I really reccomend this restaurant!

This place is solid when it comes to buffets. if youre looking for japanese cuisine and some good sushi (not the best) then you should come here. they dont offer alot of seafood besides crab legs and mussels and sushi but its definitely not worth the price.. for maybe $17 i would come here more often but if the price point stays in the $25 area youre better off going to eat AYCE sushi
El mejor sushi de las vegas tienen como 20 tipos diferentes ya hechos y cuenta con comida caliente patas de cangrejo rostbeef y barra de postres Buffet cuesta 28 dlls adultos y 15 los niños

***3.5 stars***

If you like sushi, rolls, crab legs (dinner only), and Japanese food, this is a good solid place to go to for $26.

Don't expect a 5 star sushi quality food place...expect a pretty good for your money sushi buffet.

Their sushi comprises mostly of a buffet of creative sushi roll pieces.  For those who want sashimi pieces, salmon and tuna were available as well.  Their hot buffet includes miso soup, tempura shrimp and vegetables, sukiyaki, calamari, and other hot dishes.

They charge 25 cents for the rice on every piece of sushi you don't finish...which I thought was cheap.  

They are located on Flamingo and Decatur on a strip mall to the right of Flamingo, off the strip.  If you like sushi rolls and Japanese food, this is a great place to go to.
This is my favorite out of all places!! I go there a lot and have never been disappointed!!! Every time my friends come from out of town I make sure we go there!

Great price for the food you get.  I went here recently during my stay in Vegas and it was well worth the buck.  There's made to order crepes and ice cream.  The sushi is good, I like the hot foods too.

Pretty decent buffet spot if you are visiting Vegas. 
Sushi bar is good and Asian food. But what really got me was their desserts. I love flan and they had different types! Their macaroons were good! You should come here hungry. I'd like to see what is on the menu for dinner.

This is my kin'of buffet! Seafood here seafood there! Hey don't let the seafood stuff fool you, there is is a HUGE selection of everything... Oh my the salad bar is a plus! And the desserts are heaven... chomp chomp chomp... sushi everywhere if you are a big sushi eater. This place gets pack so play your time accordingly and get there before you get too hungry! But I bet you'll love it. If you have a big party reservation can be done.... 31.00 buckaroos for dinner ( rounding it up to the nearest dollar) and 15 bucks for the keikis ( kids) . So happy Makino chomping! Yes.... :)
The service is good but the food was aight!!!! Way over priced. I can't believe this place got a 3 1/2 stars! No plans of comingback here, and definitely will not recomend to friends.
That's the best quality buffet I tried so far. Better quality and better taste than anywhere else. That's the place where locals eat. Friendly staff. Good varieties. Will come back.

Pretty bomb as far as AYCE sushi goes. Yes, it's a little pricey at dinner, but the food stays hot and fresh. The sushi selection is nice, but they have an array of other AYCE entrees as well. If you just want to try it out, but not sure you want to spend $22 for dinner, go there for lunch for $16 a person.

Besides, who doesn't love all you can eat fresh shrimp tempura?

The quality does NOT justify the price. Perhaps my standards are too high, but most of the sushi here was sick. Chewy fish, smelly fish, discolored fish.. I really don't see how you guys can eat this stuff! I'm giving them 2 stars rather than 1 for the sheer variety, but man the quality is low. 

The chocolate fountain was a nice touch.. but the snowcones weren't good. Overall I would never come back. Ew.

When you go to Vegas, you think that each buffet is the same except for the price you pay... Makino is an Asian inspired buffet that is located off the strip. It's in the plaza where Smith's is. It's always packed and even though there is a wait, you don't wait for hours to eat.

Place is tight but enough for you to move around. Selection of the food is limited but it is within their theme --- Asian. Food is yummy and nor overwhelming. It's a more relaxed resto if you ask me.

This place is better than the average run of the mill sushi buffet place, but why not save your pennies for a they-make-it-as-you go sushi joint?  The only great thing about this sushi place is that there is a lot of variety.  The fish doesn't taste bad, but quality is just not as great as it could be.

The wait staff is very good; it's almost like the drinks are refilling themselves automatically.

BEST PLACE TO SATISFY YOUR SUSHI CRAVINGS. Buffet style all you can eat. They never run out of sushi when you come back to get more. They also have some chinewe food, ramen, sukiyaki, baked clams and fish, and dessert. Try their red bean icecream.

Today, May 14, 2015, my friend and I decided to give Makino a try for lunch. OMG, what a surprise.  I expected the food to be good, but it was so-o-o-o good.  Everything was flavorable and delicious.  we eat so much.  Each bit was more delicious than the last bite.  I love Todai Sushi Buffet but I hate going on the Strip.  Because Makino is on Decatur, it's easily accessible and the buffet is great for the price.  Give them a chance, I guarantee you will not be disappointed.

Huge selection of different makizushi rolls. Typical selection of nigirizushi, but the quality was that which you would expect of sushi purchased from within a large chain grocery store (it is a buffet, afterall).

The crab legs were my favorite item since I don't get an opportunity to feast on them often. My guess is the crab legs are prepared by boiling them.  The boil is aggresively brined and I would have eaten more crab legs but they were way too salty. I liken it to the movie theater that oversalts their popcorn so you eat less and drink more. Despite the imbalance, I would return tomorrow to have them again if I had time. 

Overall, I agree with the majority of yelpers and the 4 star rating. There is something for everyone here.  I would return and I recommend this restaurant to others.

For some reason or another, a trip to Makino everytime I'm in Vegas to see the folks has unknowingly become a Chang family tradition. Sure that didn't occur without some major arm twisting, since the place is not cheap, but somehow every holiday break, we find ourselves cruising along Decatur, ready for some fish.

About the food, to be completely frank I never know how to judge buffets. Let's see... Price? As stated, the place isn't cheap but lunch is pretty affordable ($15) with pretty much the same selection as dinner ($25) except with crab legs and some more seafood stuffs.  Food? If Japanese food means chicken teriyaki and sushi, then you have Japanese food coming out the woodworks. They have different combinations of sushi, from spicy tuna inside, unagi outside, unagi inside, spicy tuna outside, california roll with spicy tuna outside, etc. you get the point: limited fillings but done in different combinations for your pleasure. Selection is pretty vast so whether you're hankering for greens, fish, desserts, noodles, poultry, red meat, soup, or otherwise, you'll probably find it here, done with an East Asian flair. 

Freshness? Dinner seems more and more a rip since some items seem to be left over from lunch, but their King Crab Legs are super fresh and my mom always makes sure we get our $25 a head's worth in lump crab meat. For the record, I hate dissecting crab legs, I never had the talent for such a task. But the legs here are surprisingly easy to break apart, if that's any consolation. The sushi is usually pretty fresh, but like I said, sometimes you can tell the stuff was left over from lunch and the sashimi gets a bit dried out. Not a big deal, I haven't gotten sick off this place (yet). 

Service? The wait staff seats you and takes your empty plates away. They fill drinks and don't talk to you. Nothing spectacular. Trying to get ice cream from the staff behind the dessert counter seems a bit more arduous, but come on, it's ice cream, you can work for it. Prices are the same on holidays and weekends as weekdays (lunch $15, dinner $25) so don't hesitate to stop by on a weekend when the turnover is higher. 

Overall, I find it a better value than buffets a mile down on the strip, so if you're hankering for uncontrolled access to calories, try driving those couple extra blocks away from Las Vegas Blvd.

5 stars for both customer service and variety of food.
There is a huge variety of sushi and seafood dishes. If you're expecting Morimoto quality seafood, then don't. The price you pay for a dinner here (around $30) is worth for the amount/quality of food you get. My experience here was great, and our server was very attentive. If I'm ever back in Vegas, I would definitely come back!

I am from Houston and this buffet was pretty decent for what you get. They have a sushi bar along with a ramen bar and other hot foods and a salad section. You can order handrolls 2 at a time. I did see a lot of people getting nigiri but I have trust issues so I didn't venture into that. I had a flight to catch in a few hours and didn't want to risk it.

Their beef sukiyaki soup was great. I did enjoy the shrimp tempura and steak teriyaki. Love that they had mini seafood pancakes! I wish they had spider handrolls that would have been awesome but hey can't have it all. They had green tea ice cream which I got on my way out.

I haven't been here in about 10 years and this place is still busy. The menu didn't change much and the food is decent. I think the sushi is still freshly made, but it doesn't taste the same. Maybe it's because I've been eating in different sushi restaurants. The food is still worth the price.
Makino is only buffet restaurant I go when ever I want AYCE. I have tried some local Chinese buffet restaurants buy any one of them was good. Makinos food is not excellent but not bad for the price.

My husband and I eat there all the time.  I love their salad selections.  i am a vegetarian and am pleased that they offer vegetarian options.  However, when they offer tofu, I wish they wouldn't put it next to the meat.  You can't get a better deal for the price!

While the service is good, the quality of the food withers... My family and I ate at this Makino a couple of years ago, and it tasted a lot better. But when I tried it again the food was just not as good. Great place to solve your sushi cravings... but not for quality.

We came on a Tuesday afternoon and AYCE for lunch is about $17

- Definitely had to update my last review because this time Makino delivered!
- Lunch is similar to Dinner, but way cheaper. No crab legs or oysters.
